Award.AwardTitle: A Stochastic and Computational Approach for Fracture Modeling of Quasi-Brittle Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is an increasing need to predict materials response and failure behavior at macroscopic scale from its microstructural composition. In brittle and quasi-brittle materials, such as glass, concrete, rocks, and ceramics, failure is particularly sensitive to the microstructure leading to a large scatter in failure loads. Most existing fracture models fail to reliably predict this scatter. This award supports fundamental research in developing theoretical and computational tools for fracture of brittle and quasi-brittle materials that directly link their microstructure to failure loads and the scatter observed. Brittle and quasi-brittle fracture mechanics finds applications in a variety of material and structural designs and plays a central role in many other fields. For example, ceramics are used with metals to develop high-strength and light-weight materials for armor designs and aerospace industry. Rock fracture, whether occurring naturally as in earthquake or manmade for enhanced oil recovery and CO2 sequestration is another example. Finally, obtaining more accurate probabilities of fracture reduces uncertainties in current design practices and can aid in the assessment of the structural integrity of existing infrastructure systems. Educational goals focus on development of short course toolkits on random models and computational tools to attract high school students to STEM fields, and software modules that will be shared with scientific community.

The field of stochastic partial differential equations provides systematic approaches for the propagation of randomness in an analysis in general. However, there is currently no means to relate material microstructures to initial random field description needed for these stochastic models. This research fills the knowledge gap by deriving continuum models that directly translate microstructure distribution to the initial material field description. Unlike common homogenization schemes, stochastic representative volume elements still preserve the spatial variability and randomness of material. This enables realistic modeling of brittle and quasi-brittle fracture. To ensure accurate rendering of this theoretical model an advanced finite element model is formulated that can efficiently capture complicated fracture patterns by incorporating both bulk and interfacial failure mechanisms. Moreover, a novel adaptive computational scheme eliminates the sensitivity of the failure load on initial mesh discretization and guarantees the estimation of probability of failure within the user-specified error bounds. The microstructure-based probabilistic fracture model approach aims to explain a variety of phenomena that are not well captured with commonly used deterministic models. Some examples are size effect in brittle and quasi-brittle materials, scatter in failure load, and formation of complex fracture patterns even under uniform loads.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were the characterization of material structure at the microscale, homogenization of elastic and fracture properties at the mesoscale, and their use as input material properties for macroscopic failure analysis.

An important aspect of this project was the length scale at which elastic and fracture properties were homogenized. In homogenization, a Volume Element (VE) is generally large enough to be considered representative. That is, for a stationary (macroscopically homogeneous) macroscopic region, the same set of properties are homogenized at all points by using Representative Volume Elements (RVEs). While the use of RVEs is widespread for linear analysis, there are some concerns on their use for failure analysis.

Maintaining material inhomogeneities is critical in capturing realistic fracture patterns due to stress concentration, stress shielding and other forms of stress field inhomogeneities induced by such material inhomogeneities. Moreover, fracture response, especially post-ultimate load, can be highly stochastic particularly for quasi-brittle materials. When the VE is not large enough to be considered representative, it still can be used to homogenize the effect of material microstructure to mesoscopic properties. These VEs are called Statistical Volume Elements (SVEs). Unlike RVEs, the use of SVEs, not only maintains material inhomogeneities but also results in different statistical realization of the same material geometry. The former aspect can maintain sufficient material inhomogeneity at the mesoscale to enable capturing realistic fracture patterns. Moreover, since the SVE-based homogenized properties exhibit statistical variations, its multiscale failure analysis can capture the scatter in response post past peak load.

Figure 1 shows three types of SVEs used for homogenizing elastic and fracture properties of microcracked rock and two-phase composites in collaboration with the University of Saint Thomas (UST) and the Ohio State University (OSU). The one-point Probability Distribution Function (PDF) and two-point covariance function of homogenized fields shown in figure 2 are two functions that were used to realize statistically consistent random fields. The numerically calibrated size effect shows the decrease of the mean and statistical variations of material strength for a VE as the VE size increases.

The statistics of the homogenized properties and Karhunen-Loeve and other methods are used to realize statistically consistent mesoscopic fields for elastic and fracture properties. These fields are used for macroscopic fracture analysis. Figure 3 shows how direct discretization and adaptive operations of the Spacetime Discontinuous Galerkin method in spacetime enable capturing complex fracture patterns at the macroscale.

The advantage of using SVEs is shown in Figure 4. The top row shows three random fields for fracture strength realized based on the statistics of 1x1, 2x2, and 8x8 SVEs, plus one with a uniform value. The fracture patterns in the bottom row show that when a uniform fracture strength field is used or a large VE is used for homogenization, the fragmentation patterns are not realistic and lack microcracking and crack branching events that are observed in dynamic brittle fracture.

Figure 5 shows the propagation of inhomogeneity from the micro to meso and to macro scales. For a Yuen-Long marble 5 different microcrack length distributions with identical mean crack length are chosen. A sample mesoscopic fracture strength field and the PDFs of mesoscopic fracture strength fields are shown next. A sample macroscopic fracture solution and the macroscopically averaged strain versus stress responses corresponding to the 5 different microcrack length models are shown next. The domain with wider variations of crack length results in 3x lower ultimate load and 6x lower dissipated energy, but a more ductile failure response. This demonstrates the high effect of material microstructure on macroscopic response and the potential to optimize a material?s macroscopic response by designing its microstructure.

Finally, a stochastic bulk damage model was formulated to reduce computational costs compared to the sharp interfacial model used in preceding examples. Figure 6 shows that as the correlation length of the random field for fracture strength decreases, a bulk damage model under uniform stress field can capture failure localization zones, an aspect not observed with conventional damage models.

During this project, 4 graduate students (2 funded by the project) at the University of Tennessee (UT), 3 undergraduate students (through ROA and REU supplementary awards), and 2 graduate students at OSU were trained and conducted research on stochastic fracture mechanics. Five universities (UT, UST, OSU, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and University of Texas A&M) collaborated for this project. Some of the research findings of this course were included in a fracture mechanics course taught by the PI.

The same approaches can be applied to ductile fracture, although statistical variation of fracture response is not as severe. This methodology can find application in rock fracture (earthquake, hydraulic fracturing, geothermal energy, and CO2 sequestration), armor design, and in bone fracture. The statistical concepts related to SVEs can be applied to model random media in thermal, acoustic, and electromagnetic problems.

    Reza Abedi, Philip Clarke

    The effect of SVE size
  • One- and Two-point statistics of mesoscopic fracture strength and the size effect plot that shows that the mean and variations of fracture strength decreases as the SVE size increases.
    Reza Abedi, Philip Clarke, Katherine Acton, Sara Baxter
    Public Domain
    Reza Abedi
    Statistics of mesoscopic fields
  • Direct discretization and adaptive operations of the spacetime discontinuous Galerkin method in spacetime enables capturing complex fracture patterns in brittle fracture by aligning element boundaries with predicted crack paths.
    Reza Abedi, Robert Haber, Jeff Erickson, Shripad Thite, Shuo-Heng Cheng, Michael Garland
    Public Domain
    Reza Abedi
    Spacetime Discontinuous Galerkin method
  • Three different SVE types used for the homogenization of mesoscopic elastic and fracture properties of rock and two-phase composites.
    Reza Abedi, Katherine Acton, Soheil Soghrati, Ming Yang
    Copyrighted
    Reza Abedi
    SVE types
  • Propagation of the effect of microstructure to mesoscopic fields and to macroscopic fracture response. The rock sample with the widest range of microcrack length results in 3x lower strength and 6x lower energy, but a more ductile response at the macroscale.
    Reza Abedi, Justin Garrard
    Public Domain
    Reza Abedi
    Propagation of statistics across scales
  • By decreasing the correlation length of the random field for rock cohesion, localized fracture zones under uniaxial compressive loading can be captured by a bulk damage model.
    Reza Abedi, Bahador Bahmani, Philip Clarke
    Public Domain
    Reza Abedi
    The effect of inhomogeneity on localization of fracure for tbulk damage models

Unlike RVEs, the use of SVEs, not only maintains material inhomogeneities but also results in different statistical realization of the same material geometry.
